6\ What if they abuse your trust and share keys with 3rd parties in a way you don't like?

1) You can tell it was them: your BIP32-comm device can identify the original extended private key you shared

2) You can "burn" that particular private key: none of its children will work

1105514023255195649.text:
5\ They can even generate their own (child) private keys and pass those to 3rd parties, pre-authorizing them to reach you 1-time only.

Or they can generate *extended* private keys, enabling 3rd parties to reach out directly, as often as necessary.

1105514022655414273.text:
4\ But what if you want someone to be able to reach you directly without you having to pre-authorize it?

Just generate an *extended* private key for them. They can use this extended key to generate private keys for each message they want to send you, no pre-auth required.

1105514022005342210.text:
3\ Your comm device would only allow 1 msg from this private key to hit your inbox -- others would be rejected/filtered out.

If you respond, within your response will be embedded another private key they can use to reply.

A conversation thread becomes a sequence of transactions

1105514021225226240.text:
2\ You meet someone who asks for your phone/email -- instead of giving them the actual number/address, you give them your root public key and generate a child *private* key for them from your BIP32-like comm. device.

They send you a msg to your pubkey signing with the privkey.

1105514020604399616.text:
1\ You know what would be cool? If phone numbers & email (comms in general) worked on a hierarchical public/private keypair model such as BIP32.

6\ If Bitcoin were an engine, dust would be part of its waste heat, its exhaust.

Bitcoin uses a lot of energy, it'd be nice if we could define an *energy efficiency* for it -- how well does it protect us, given how much energy it uses?

This metric should understand dust.

1075054123416989698.text:
5\ How to stop dust? (If you care)

Spring cleaning: coordinated, yearly attempts to consolidate dust.
Fee holiday: miners process dust "for free" to clean chain
New code: developers have the most power

But probably, nothing we do will stop dust. Dust is inherent inefficiency.

1075054122594910210.text:
4\ We calculate an average # of bytes to spend a UTXO and use this to draw the historical dust line.

Here are the numbers:

Dec. 2017: ~25-50% UTXOs dust ($25-50M)
Dec. 2018: ~10-15% UTXOs dust (only $300k!)

Dust IS and IS NOT a problem!

1075054121684819968.text:
3\ First: how do we recognize dust? A UTXO can be dust today but not tomorrow, depending on how the tx fee market changes.

We define a UTXO's *value density* -- the # of Satoshi contained in that UTXO per byte it takes to spend it in a tx.

Value Density > Lowest Fee Rate? Dust!

1075054120745218049.text:
2\ Authoring Bitcoin transactions at scale is a difficult optimization problem with no globally best solution (thanks @lopp). #DustHappens

Dust production began in 2012 but got severe in 2017. It's better now, but might be worse again.

Care to guess how much dust there is?

961690936328818688.text:
14\ Today's analogy for light-lag is low-bandwidth: both limit your ability to mine and thus cause centralization. Some ignore this issue, but it's real.

Lesson: Increasing block sizes with constant network connectivity speeds disadvantages miners with low-bandwidth (~light-lag)

961690935250837505.text: 13\ Hashpower ratios between star systems are also critical. If hashpower on Earth is many times that of α-Centauri, newly mined blocks on α-Centauri will constantly get uncled. Users on α-Centauri will only trust Earth blocks. Mining will become centralized to Earth: colonialism

961690934076497920.text:
12\ For blockchains, this problem could not be solved with bigger/faster blocks -- the only way to deal with the uncertainty caused by light lag is to wait.

Lesson: Different chains do different things.  Layers (#LightningNetwork) and sidechains are necessary for space-coffees.

961690932604297216.text:
11\ Such a system could never be used for day-to-day transactions (space-coffees). Something else would be necessary.

Banks might let you borrow against your holdings in another star system until they can be transferred locally (and your opportunity to double-spend eliminated).

961690930993618944.text: 10\ I think that "long integration times" must be part of the solution: a 20-year "pending transaction period" for a bank or a 20-year target block time for a blockchain. Combine that with still "waiting for 6 confirmations" and you get century-long transaction timescales. #whoa

961690929689227264.text:
9\ I'm writing about these problems not just because they're fun but because I think they motivate clearer thinking about distributed systems here on Earth, today.

961690928535752704.text:
8\ These examples are not pathologies. They are fundamental problems of interstellar commerce.

957723616124309504.text: 10\ Computation isn't love or empathy, more is not always better.

957723615126016003.text: 9\ An opposite example: #mimblewimble uses an *even more limited* computing system than Bitcoin Script. This tradeoff allows for a degree of homomorphic encryption which creates better scaling & complete transaction privacy. Bitcoin & Ethereum can't do this: they are "too smart"!

957723614035566592.text: 8\ IANA Bitcoin maximalist. Turing-complete blockchains like Ethereum are extremely valuable. But they are building a "world computer", not creating sound money. The use case is different, so the code is different, and the scaling process more difficult. But just as worthwhile!

957723612995358720.text: 7\ Why so much caution? B/c unbounded computation is *dangerous* when you're trying to build sound money! Turing-complete systems are harder to constrain & scaling is ultimately about the engineering of constraints. So if you want blockchain Visa you might need to give up Turing!

957723611762253824.text: 6\ Bitcoin's creators were judicious in their choices for opcodes in Bitcoin Script b/c they *did not want* Turing-completeness! As the network matured, more complex scripts were allowed. But slowly, so as to *avoid* unintended consequences & stay computationally "sub-critical".

957723610214486017.text: 5\ Here are some examples of systems that are accidentally Turing-complete: #MagicTheGathering, #PowerPoint slides, HTML5&CSS3, #Minecraft, #Pokemon Yellow, #Braid, and my fav. example, #SuperMarioBros on the SNES (thanks @gwern for your great list): http://www.gwern.net/Turing-complete

957723609040121871.text: 4\ Similarly, once a threshold in capabilities is passed, computing systems become Turing-complete and the possibilities they can express runs away, unboundedly. The hard part isn't *becoming* Turing-complete when you want to, it's *avoiding* it when you don't: sub-criticality.

957723607886630913.text: 3\ ...Turing-completeness is like a nuclear explosion. Once the threshold density/temperature is breached, fission fuel self-ignites and explodes. The hard part isn't blowing past the threshold, but staying as close to it as possible: energy => criticality => balance => control.

957723606850703366.text: 2\ This is a blatant misunderstanding! To a non-technical person, Turing-completeness and being able to compute anything is *obviously* better. But programmers know that Turing-completeness is Pandora's box: you don't know what it contains and you can't close it once opened...

957723605688897541.text: 1\ Have you heard this reasoning? "#Ethereum is better than #Bitcoin because it can do more." => "The EVM is Turing-complete and Bitcoin Script isn't, so Ethereum is a better cryptocurrency." => "Bitcoin's creators were too early/stupid/blind to make Bitcoin Turing-complete."

955236778306424832.text: 9\ #crypto requires depth: you must understand distributed systems, cryptography, economics, & politics. If you don't grok all these subjects (I don't), read people that do. Don't #DunningKruger yourself. Don't enable #cryptocranks. And maybe make friends with more physicists :)

955236777396195328.text: 8\ If you believe in crank quantum mechanics the worst you will suffer is some magical thinking. But the consequences in #crypto are more tragic: you can lose your livelihood if you fall for #cryptocranks. How to protect yourself?

955236775936618496.text: 7\ Like physics, #blockchains are an abstract subject filled with specialized jargon. Good #cryptocranks push content which *looks like* a real project (has a "whitepaper", some GitHub links, maybe some math) and lay-investors buy into it b/c they can't tell the difference.

955236774065917952.text: 6\ But what if, beyond intellectual recognition, there were *direct* monetary rewards in doing original physics? If you could make $100M if the world "bought into" your crank theory, how many more cranks would there be? I submit to you this is the situation in #cryptocurrency !

955236772987965442.text: 5\ But what motivates cranks in the first place? The need to be perceived as brilliant. Cranks work in esoterica because its remoteness from experience allows them to convince themselves and their followings they are the next Einstein. Maybe even do a book tour and make some $.

955236771427749890.text: 4\ Physicists can tell the difference b/c we are trained. We see broken arguments through the veneer of crank-math. We aren't awed by technical jargon such as "wave function". Our depth of knowledge protects us from falsity. So when we get an email from a crank, we recognize it.

955236770228195330.text: 3\ Bad cranks are just crazy people. But good cranks are interesting. Their work *looks like* physics (has math, equations, diagrams) and, because its engaging an abstract subject like quantum mechanics, can be mistaken for real physics by laypeople who can't tell the difference.

955236769355661313.text: 2\ Why these subjects? B/c they are abstract & esoteric. It's hard to crank in Newtonian mechanics because your bogus theory is easily disproved by direct human experience. It's easier to crank in quantum b/c few outside the tribe of physics really understand quantum mechanics.

955236768500125697.text: 1\ Physicists have a word "crank": a person who doesn't know physics but persists in promulgating their personal theory. Cranks pop in all fields of physics but especially in certain areas: quantum mechanics, field theories, relativity, cosmology, &c.

Instead of packets, we could have "chain letters" signed by each node relaying data: both transport & transaction in the same data structure.

946159253538181127.text: 10\ If you were against #NetNeutrality b/c you believe it's good for access to disparate content to cost differing amounts, you will love mesh networks: popular content will be cheaper & esoteric content more expensive, balanced by public markets for data replication & transport.

946159252481167360.text: 9\ If 47% of households are watching the season finale of #GameofThrones right now in my neighborhood then a well-built mesh network should be *faster* than traditional networks, not slower. More *efficient*, not more ponderous.  And content owners could still be paid!

941732152999280640.text: 1\ Finally received my brand new copy of Dimon's "Bitcoin FUD for Dummies: How bankers can dispense disdainful opinions on cryptocurrency without having to learn anything about it."  It's seriously a great read!  Some of my favorite parts:

941378988714455043.text: 2\ Society needs a wireless mesh networking layer built on a blockchain with token economics that incentivize a new, distributed telecom infrastructure, one in which user privacy and equal access to content are designed in from the beginning.  No more relying on 535 legislators.
